section.title: Overview
section.p: Complex multi-service systems require an adequate number of working instances to carry out the assigned work load. Systems not working at rated performance, or not working at all need to be recognized. The NCC monitors numerous parameters in a network along with the health and integrity of the servers. The system health is a resultant value derived from the health of constituent components.

The NCC monitors the components of an ME and SM using a heartbeat, which allows a site to communicate status about their own connectivity and composite state, as well as their view of the other known NCC sites.
HA configurations have a number of built in commands that monitor the following:

li.p: a node’s role as either Active or Standby
the status of all the services monitored by the HA node as to whether they are healthy or not

section.note: All system components register themselves with Monitoring. All vital services in a site must be present with a status of UP before Diameter traffic can start in the system. This applies to system starts and restarts. If the system components are not ready on the initial start up, the system will not start and you will get a time out message. Ensure the services are all UP. If you are restarting the system, you can use the sps-status tool to verify service status and take the necessary actions to ensure services are all UP. See the sections that describe “NCC service monitoring” and the “sps-status tool” in the NCC Administration Guide for more information.
section.p: The NCC monitors services on the following nodes. Each service is associated with a redundancy model of 1+1, or N+K, or Standalone.
